sen.j: 皇別（こうべつ）もしくは王孫（おうそん）とは、王家や帝家、とりわけ日本の天皇家の一門の中で臣籍降下した分流・庶流の氏族を指す言葉である。
sen.e: Kobetsu or oson is a word to refer to shizoku (clan, family), a split family or branch family of a royal family or imperial family, especially in Japan a family which has seceded from the Imperial Family.
Kobetsu or oson is a term that refers to shizoku (clan, family), a branch family of a royal family or imperial family, especially a family which has seceded from Japanese Imperial Family.
sen.cmt: split familyは「引き裂かれた家族」というイメージを与えるため削除しました。分流、庶流は、いずれも本家ではないという意味で使用されているため'branch family'のみの英訳で問題ないと考えました。
sen.e: Kobetsu or oson is a term that refers to shizoku (clan, family), a branch family of a royal family or imperial family, especially a family which has seceded from Japanese Imperial Family.

sen.j: 天皇家同様男子血統でつながらなければならない。
sen.e: Like the Imperial Family, it must be connected by a male blood line.
Like the Imperial Family, it must share the common agnate blood line.
sen.cmt: be connected by -> share「男子血統」は'agnate blood line'に変更しました。
sen.e: Like the Imperial Family, it must share the common agnate blood line.

sen.j: 皇別とは弘仁6年（815年）に朝廷が編纂した古代氏族の系譜集『新撰姓氏録』が、皇別（天皇・皇子の子孫）・神別（天津神・国津神の子孫）・諸蕃（朝鮮半島・中国大陸その他から渡来した人々の子孫）の3種に氏族を分類していることにちなむ用語である。
sen.e: Kobetsu is a term associated with the classifications of three kinds of shizokus, namely Kobetsu (descendents of Emperors and Crown Princes), Shinbetsu (descendents of Amatsukami [god of heaven] and Kunitsukami [god of the land]), and Shoban (foreign lands) (descendents of immigrants from Korean Peninsula, Mainland China, and other areas) described in "Shinsen Shojiroku (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility), a genealogy of ancient cognate clans compiled by the Chotei (Imperial Court) in 815.

Kobetsu is a term associated with the classifications of three kinds of shizokus, namely Kobetsu (descendents of Emperors and Imperial Princes), Shinbetsu (descendents of Amatsukami [god of heaven] and Kunitsukami [god of the land]), and Shoban (descendents of immigrants from Korean Peninsula, Mainland China, and other areas) described in "Shinsen Shojiroku (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility), a genealogy of ancient cognate clans compiled by the Chotei (Imperial Court) in 815.
sen.cmt: Crown Princes は皇太子を意味するため、Imperial Princesに変更しました。「諸蕃」の定訳には補足説明で(foreign ｌands)とありますが、原文では「諸蕃」を士族の一つと記載しており、定訳の補足説明を記載すると紛らわしくなるため削除しました。
sen.e: Kobetsu is a term associated with the classifications of three kinds of shizokus, namely Kobetsu (descendents of Emperors and Imperial Princes), Shinbetsu (descendents of Amatsukami [god of heaven] and Kunitsukami [god of the land]), and Shoban (descendents of immigrants from Korean Peninsula, Mainland China, and other areas) described in "Shinsen Shojiroku (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility), a genealogy of ancient cognate clans compiled by the Chotei (Imperial Court) in 815.

sen.j: 江戸時代以降は王孫という呼び名も用いられた。
sen.e: Since the Edo period the term 'oson' also has been used.
Since the Edo period, the term 'oson' also has been used.
sen.cmt: period と theの間にカンマを追記しました。
sen.e: Since the Edo period, the term 'oson' also has been used.

sen.j: 皇別・王孫は天皇が大王であった古代から存在し、財政や後継者争いの防止の観点から現天皇と血筋が遠くなった傍流の皇族や、天皇の子供でも側室やめかけの子供であるものに苗字を与える形で誕生した。
sen.e: Kobetsu/oson have existed since the ancient times when the emperor was an okimi (great king) and were created by giving family names to branch imperial families whose lineage to the Emperor has grown remote or to children of emperors born from their concubines from the viewpoint of preventing financial troubles and succession races.

Kobetsu/oson existed from the ancient times when Emperor was called Okimi (great king), and were created by giving family names to branch Imperial families whose lineage to the Emperor became remote or to children whose mothers were mistresses or concubines of the Emperor in order to prevent financial troubles and succession races.
sen.cmt: emperor was okimi -> Emperor was called Okimigrown remote -> became remote
sen.e: Kobetsu/oson existed from the ancient times when Emperor was called Okimi (great king), and were created by giving family names to branch Imperial families whose lineage to the Emperor became remote or to children whose mothers were mistresses or concubines of the Emperor in order to prevent financial troubles and succession races.

sen.j: 彼らは皇族に順ずる存在として高い尊敬を受けたが、やがて藤原家の外戚政治が確立していく中、2・3代ほどで没落する例がほとんどになった。
sen.e: They received high respect as the existence of quasi-Imperial families, but while the Fujiwara family achieved maternal relative politics, most of them fell after the second or third generations.

They received high respect as quasi-Imperial families, but as the Fujiwara family established the political system which was to hold the power as maternal relatives through marring their daughters to the members of the Imperial family, most of the families fell during the second or third generations.
sen.cmt: maternal relative politics -> 意訳しました。
sen.e: They received a lot of respect as quasi-imperial families, but as the Fujiwara family established a political system which involved holding onto power as maternal relatives by marrying their daughters to members of the imperial family, most of the families fell into ruin during the second or third generations.

sen.j: 皇別氏族の中には地方で武士の棟梁として活躍するものもおり、桓武平氏と清和源氏はその代表例である。
sen.e: Some of families which branched out from the Imperial family were active as Toryo (leader) of samurai (warriors) in chiho (regions), represented by Kanmu-Heishi (TAIRA clan originated from Emperor Kanmu) and Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa).

Some families which were derived from the Imperial family flourished as Toryo (leader) of samurai (warriors) in the provinces, and famous examples are Kanmu-Heishi (TAIRA clan) and Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan).
sen.cmt: branched out -> were derived fromchiho -> the provincesrepresented by -> famous examples are「清和源氏」用語統一リストに合わせました。桓武平氏は清和源氏の表記に合わせました。
sen.e: Some families which were derived from the Imperial family flourished as Toryo (leader) of samurai (warriors) in the provinces, and famous examples are Kanmu-Heishi (TAIRA clan) and Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan).

sen.j: 9世紀には桓武天皇の5世孫である桓武平氏の平将門が新皇として短い間ではあったが関東に君臨した。
sen.e: In the 9th century Kanmu-Heishi's TAIRA no Masakado, the 5th generation descendant of Emperor Kanmu reigned over Kanto as a new emperor though for a short period of time.
In the 9th century, TAIRA no Masakado from Kanmu-Heishi, the 5th generation descendant of Emperor Kanmu, reigned over Kanto region as a new emperor for a short period of time.
sen.cmt: 桓武平氏と平将門の語順を入れ替えました。Kanmu と reignedの間にカンマを追記しました。
sen.e: In the 9th century, TAIRA no Masakado from Kanmu-Heishi, the 5th generation descendant of Emperor Kanmu, reigned over Kanto region as a new emperor for a short period of time.

sen.j: また日本で最初に政権を取った武家は、桓武平氏の平清盛であるとされている。
sen.e: And it is said that the first buke (samurai family) who take control of the government in Japan was TAIRA no Kiyomori of Kanmu-Heishi.
And it is said that the first buke (samurai family) who took control of the government in Japan was TAIRA no Kiyomori from Kanmu-Heishi.

sen.j: 清和源氏は源頼朝が平氏本家を打ち破った後鎌倉に幕府を開き、3代にわたって東日本を統治した結果、武家の盟主として広く認められるようになった。
sen.e: Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) established the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in Kamakura after MINAMOTO no Yoritomo defeated the Taira clan's head family and came out to be recognized as a leader of buke (military authority) as a result of controlling the east Japan for three generations.

Seiwa-Genji established the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in Kamakura after MINAMOTO no Yoritomo defeated Taira clan's head family and became widely known as a leader of buke (military authority) through controlling the east Japan for three generations.
sen.cmt: came out to be recognized -> became widely known
sen.e: Seiwa-Genji established the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in Kamakura after MINAMOTO no Yoritomo defeated Taira clan's head family and became widely known as a leader of buke (military authority) through controlling the east Japan for three generations.

sen.j: 後に源氏の分家である足利家は室町幕府を開き、武士の勢力の伸張と天皇家の権威・権力の衰退にも助けられ、15代240年にわたり征夷大将軍として日本に君臨し、外交、内政、軍事を差配した。
sen.e: Later the Ashikaga family, a branch family of the Minamoto clan established Muromachi bakufu, and partly because of the expansion of the power of bushi (warriors) and the decline of the authority and power of the Emperor, reined over Japan as Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") and controlled foreign affairs, domestic administration, andmilitary affairs over 15 generations and 240 years.

Later the Ashikaga family, a branch family of the Minamoto clan established Muromachi bakufu, and partly because of the expansion of the power of bushi (warriors) and the decline of the authority and power of the Emperor, reigned over Japan as Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") and conducted foreign affairs, domestic administration, and military affairs over 15 generations for 240 years.

Later the Ashikaga family, a branch family of the Minamoto clan established Muromachi bakufu, and partly because of the expansion of the power of bushi (warriors) and the decline of the authority and power of the Emperor, reigned over Japan as Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") and conducted foreign affairs, domestic administration, and military affairs over 15 generations for 240 years.

sen.j: また公家の間にも引き続いて天皇家から高位の公家に養子に入る形での皇別氏族が誕生した。
sen.e: In the meantime, kobetsu shizoku (families branched out from the Imperial family) came into being in the form of adoption into high-ranking court nobles from the Imperial Family.
In the meantime, kobetsu shizoku (families derived from the Imperial family) were established by high-ranking court nobles adopting members of the Imperial family.
In the meantime, kobetsu shizoku (families derived from the Imperial family) were established by high-ranking court nobles adopting members of the Imperial family.

sen.j: すなわち近衛信尋以降の近衛家、一条昭良以降の一条家、鷹司輔平以降の鷹司家の3家であり、これらの分家の内男子血統で続いているものや、これらの家から養子を迎えた後男系で続いている家も含め、今日では皇別摂家と呼ばれている。
sen.e: Namely the three families consisting of the Konoe family after Nobuhiro KONOE, the Ichijo famil after Akiyoshi ICHIJO, and the Takatsukasa famil after Sukehira TAKATSUKASA, their branch families connected by male blood lines and families who adopted sons from these families are called Kobetsu Sekke (line of regents and advisers) today.

Specifically the three families including the Konoe family after the adoption of Nobuhiro KONOE, the Ichijo family after Akiyoshi ICHIJO, and the Takatsukasa family after Sukehira TAKATSUKASA, their branch families that shares agnate blood lines and the families that adopted sons from these families are called Kobetsu Sekke (line of regents and advisers) today.
sen.cmt: 「鷹司輔平以降」は「鷹司輔平が養子に迎えられた後」と解釈して英文を書き換えました。
sen.e: Specifically the three families including the Konoe family after the adoption of Nobuhiro KONOE, the Ichijo family after Akiyoshi ICHIJO, and the Takatsukasa family after Sukehira TAKATSUKASA, their branch families that shares agnate blood lines and the families that adopted sons from these families are called Kobetsu Sekke (line of regents and advisers) today.

sen.j: 天皇家の庶家としてその家系は価値を有しており、歴史上皇別・王孫の氏族の出であると偽ったものも少なくない。
sen.e: The branch families of the Imperial families maintain the value of the family lineage and not a few persons have pretended to belong to Kobetsu/Oson in history.
Being one of the branch families of the Imperial family gave the value to the family line, and not a few cases that persons pretended to be a member of Kobetsu/Oson are found in Japanese history.

sen.j: 例として徳川家康は自身を清和源氏であると捏造している。
sen.e: For example, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA made up that he belonged to Seiwa-Genji.
For example, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA made up a story that he belonged to Seiwa-Genji.

sen.j: また旧皇族も定義に従えば皇別・王孫であるが、あまりそのようには呼ばれない。
sen.e: Also, according to the definition, former Imperial Families are Kobetsu/Oson, but they are seldom called so.
According to the definition, former Imperial Families are Kobetsu/Oson, but such appellation is seldom applied to these families.
